properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Maximum gusts: Southwesterly between 100 and 130 km/h. Locations: southern half of the Burin Peninsula, most of the Avalon Peninsula. Time span: midnight tonight to Thursday morning. Remarks: After the southwesterlies diminish Thursday morning, winds will shift to northwesterly. Over the northern Avalon Peninsula winds will likely gust near 80 km/h Thursday afternoon. Additionally, large waves and pounding surf are expected in Placentia and St. Mary's Bays overnight tonight. Water levels may be higher than normal during that time giving the potential for minor coastal flooding, especially near high tide. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may cause downed trees or toss loose objects. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-09T11:13:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T19:14:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1479959283.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls ending tonight. Weakening snow squalls will continue for a few more hours. Some of these snow squalls may give snowfall accumulations near 5 centimetres by the time the squalls come to an end early tonight. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T07:59:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T23:35:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2209487711.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow expected tonight and Thursday. Total Snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: Generally northwesterly near 80 km/h. Northwesterly gusts near 100 km/h are expected in the Port aux Basques area overnight Wednesday night. Gusts near 120 km/h will develop along the northeast coast on Thursday morning. Locations: Port aux Basques to Gros Morne, Central and Northeastern Newfoundland. Time span: tonight through Thursday afternoon. Remarks: Snow at times heavy will combine with strong winds to reduce visibility in blowing snow tonight and Thursday. Conditions will gradually improve late Thursday as winds and snow diminish. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-09T11:14:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T19:15:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0950383406.2020
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Green Bay - White Bay

properties.Summary:

Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected with the heaviest amounts falling Thursday during the day. Snow will taper off Thursday evening or overnight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls continuing into this evening. Isolated snow squalls continue late this afternoon. Some of these snow squalls may give snowfall accumulations near 5 centimetres by the time the squalls come to an end early tonight. Also, strong winds gusting up to 60 km/h will combine with the fresh snow to result in local blowing snow, particularly over open areas. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant winter storm expected Saturday. A low pressure system will impact southern Ontario this weekend. Rain, freezing rain, and snow are all possible with this system. Significant rainfall amounts are expected for areas north of Lake Erie and Lake Ontario. Freezing rain is expected to affect most areas from east of Lake Huron to eastern Ontario. Significant ice accretion or build up is possible. Snow will affect areas east of Georgian Bay with significant snowfall amounts. Travel is expected to be impacted. There is still uncertainty as to which areas will be the most impacted with this system. The Ontario Storm Prediction Centre will be closely monitoring the situation. Warnings may be issued as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T12:15:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T20:16:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1070479115.2020

properties.Summary:

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Maximum wind gusts: north to northwesterly 80 km/h, with stronger gusts possible. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Location: Great Northern Peninsula. Time span: tonight and Thursday. Remarks: Modest snowfall will combine with strengthening winds to cause poor visibility in blowing snow over the Great Northern Peninsula beginning after midnight tonight. Strong winds and periods of snow will continue into Thursday morning before tapering off later in the day. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-09T11:15:31-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A low pressure system tracking eastward across southern Saskatchewan has brought snow to a large portion of southern Saskatchewan today. The heaviest amounts are expected over the northwestern and north-central grainbelt where snowfall totals of 10 to 15 cm are possible before tapering off this evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 40 to 60 cm with higher amounts likely over the Cape Breton Highlands. Location: Pictou, Antigonish, Inverness, and Victoria Counties. Time span: tonight into Thursday morning. Remarks: Moderate to heavy snow will continue tonight before slowly tapering off through the day on Thursday. However isolated snow squalls are possible tonight and Thursday as colder air moves into the region. Total amounts could exceed 60 cm in areas of heaviest snow. In addition, strong northerly winds will develop this afternoon which, given the fresh fluffy snow, will produce reduced visibility in blowing snow through tonight and Thursday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T11:50:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T19:51:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1541899867.2020
Area: Pictou County, Antigonish County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Locations: Gander and vicinity and Bonavista North. Maximum wind gusts: north to northwesterly 80 km/h, with gusts to 120 km/h along parts of the coast. Total snowfall: 10 cm tonight and 5 cm on Thursday. Time span: Later Thursday morning through Thursday evening. Remarks: Snow will develop this evening then taper off to drizzle of freezing drizzle overnight before changing back to snow before morning. Strong north to northwesterly winds will develop during the morning on Thursday and combine with the falling snow to give poor visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions will start to improve by Thursday evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-09T11:19:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T19:20:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1492162558.2020
Area: Bonavista North, Gander and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow at times heavy tapering off tonight. Total snowfall: 20 to 35 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 70 km/h. Location: central and eastern Nova Scotia. Time span: this evening Remarks: Additional snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are possible this evening before snow tapers to scattered flurries. Snow will taper off over central Nova Scotia this evening and over southeastern Cape Breton near midnight. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T13:59:20-00:00

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly near 70 km/h becoming northwesterly near 70 km/h overnight tonight. Total Snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Location: Inland over the Burgeo highway. Time span: tonight and Thursday morning. Remarks: Fresh snow and moderate winds will combine to cause poor visibility in blowing snow, especially inland along the Burgeo highway. Conditions along the coast should be less severe. Conditions will begin to improve Thursday morning as the snow tapers off. Northwesterly gusts to 70 km/h will persist until Thursday night. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

Area: Burgeo - Ramea

properties.Summary:

The warning may need to be be expanded to areas to the south over the next couple of days. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls possible this evening. Heavy lake effect flurries are currently affecting the area this evening. Some of these flurries may briefly intensify into snow squalls later this evening and give snowfall accumulations near 5 centimetres by the time the flurries come to an end near midnight. A Snow Squall Warning may be required. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: northwesterly near 120 km/h. Locations: Bonavista Peninsula and Bonavista North. Time span: Thursday morning until Thursday evening. Remarks: Strong easterly winds gusting between 70 and 80 km/h will develop this evening. Winds will briefly diminish overnight before quickly reintensifying Thursday morning from the northwest. These northwest winds will combine with falling snow to give reduced visibility at times, especially in Bonavista North. Winds will gradually diminish Thursday night. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major low pressure system will affect the province of Quebec on Saturday and Sunday. Precipitation will begin Saturday as rain over Southern Quebec and is expected to change over to freezing rain Saturday evening. The amount of freezing precipitation could be significant and make surfaces like roads, streets and sidewalks slippery and hazardous. Strong gusts of 60-70 km/h are also expected on Sunday, and may possibly impact icy structures such as tree limbs and power lines. There remains some uncertainty regarding the track of this system, which may affect total rainfall and freezing precipitation amounts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T12:33:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T20:34:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1240316059.2020
